phases.text: Welcome. Today, the Sun is our guide to how the world really works: where energy comes from, how motion creates patterns we live by, and how a simple idea can connect everyone on Earth. I’ll walk with you through three short choices. No rush, and if you want a nudge, I’ll give one.
Let’s start simple. What actually makes day and night—does the Sun circle us, or are we the ones spinning? Picture a globe on your desk and a lamp across the room.
Now imagine a plant by a window. Over a few days, does it grow evenly in every direction, or lean toward the sunlight? Picture it for a second before deciding.
Last one. Why do we have seasons—because Earth gets much farther from the Sun, or because we’re slightly tilted as we go around it? Picture a tilted globe moving around a lamp.

Wisdom to carry: one steady source, many patterns. The Sun’s light is constant; rotation and tilt turn it into day, night, and seasons. Notice one pattern today, and let it change how you see the world.
